messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of J.
B. Rainsberger

> Bradley, Todd wrote:
> > Hi, the unit test suite on a particular project of mine has grown to
> > the point where I need to organize it some. I'd like to do something
> > like Rainsberger's JUnit recipe 4.6 "Separate the different kinds of
> > test suites"***. But for some reason I can't verbalize I don't like
> > the approach of classifying tests using a tag interface.
>
> I literally move the source code: I have one source tree for
> fast tests, one for slow tests, and so on. I've never wanted
> to have a single test case class be in two categories at
> once. (Go ahead, Cedric... tell him about TestNG. :) )

Uh? Who's calling my name? Oh. Hi.

Well, since you asked...

It doesn't take a lot of tests to realize that using package and class names
to categorize your tests doesn't scale and quickly leads to very complicated
code bases.

There is also the fact that some categories transcend (or should I say
cross-cut?) packages and class names, and you give a pretty good example
yourself: slow and fast tests. Let's say I have a database and a gui
package, and on top of that, each of these categories has slow and fast
tests. How do you solve this problem?

This is precisely why we have annotations: to attach additional meaning to
Java elements (packages, classes and methods) that cannot easily be conveyed
otherwise.

As you pointed out, TestNG has the notion of groups (I believe JUnit 4 will
support this under the name "category"). Each test methods (or test
classes) can specify that it belongs to one or more groups, and you can
specify at runtime which groups to run (or not to run). For example:

package com.foo.tests.database;

public class TestDB1 {
@Test(groups = { "slow", "database" })
public void verifyEntireDataBase() {
}
}

package com.foo.tests.database;

public class TestDB2 {
@Test(groups = { "fast", "database" })
public void insertOneRecord() {
}
}

package com.foo.tests.web;

public class TestServlet {
@Test(groups = { "fast", "gui" })
public void testLoginPage() {
}
}

With this example, running TestNG on the group "fast" will invoke
"testLoginPage" and "insertOneRecord". Of course, you can also specify more
complicated patterns:

- run "fast" and "database"
- run "fast" but "not" "gui"
- run "all tests" except "gui"
- etc...

You get the idea.

I'm happy to see that this feature is being considered for inclusion in
JUnit 4, it is by far the one TestNG users like the most.
